commits.message:
Adjust div class to reflect partial name

**Prior to this commit**, when you were on the `/importers/new` page you
would see the form fields for the OAI ingester; even though you hadn't
selected that parser.

The reason is that in Bulkrax the name of the partial is used to hide
the section with a HTML class attribute that is the named
partial (e.g. `_oai_adventist_fields.html.erb` and
`class="oai_adventist_fields"`)

Below is the [Bulkrax code demonstrating that functionality][1]:

```
  <% Bulkrax.parsers.map{ |p| p[:partial]}.uniq.each do |partial| %>
  if($('.<%= partial %>').length > 0) {
    window.<%= partial %> = $('.<%= partial %>').detach()
  }
  <% end %>
```

**With this commit**, when you haven't selected a parser, there will be
no parser fields.  Then when you select the parser, the browser will
render the associated fields.

[1]:https://github.com/samvera-labs/bulkrax/blob/e88d0ea349afda5b3068836aa36ef86c93d4c62d/app/assets/javascripts/bulkrax/importers.js.erb#L112-L116

commits.message:
Restoring SETTINGS__SOLR__URL

Prior to this commit, we did not have this property.  It was removed via
061a529f.

However our `ops/env.conf` file appears to reference this value:

```shell
❯ rg SETTINGS__SOLR__URL
ops/env.conf
23:env SETTINGS__SOLR__URL;
```

With this commit, I'm restoring that setting.  I'm unclear if this will
fix the [issue that I encountered and reported in this Slack thread][1].

[1]:https://assaydepot.slack.com/archives/G0311DN2YCA/p1667582787506699

pull_request.body:

This MR updates the counter and is inspired by [this](https://gitlab.com/notch8/adventist-dl/-/blob/c924c8aed10d354d2c4992981b0905ef15a120f3/app/jobs/index_plain_text_files_job.rb) implementation.

issue.title: I127 fix CreateDerivativesJob bug
issue.body:
@jeremyf noticed that the previous implementation wouldn't have worked because the counter instance variable would've been reset at each instantiation of the job. 

This MR updates the counter and is inspired by [this](https://gitlab.com/notch8/adventist-dl/-/blob/c924c8aed10d354d2c4992981b0905ef15a120f3/app/jobs/index_plain_text_files_job.rb) implementation.

comment.body:
I want to step back from my suggestions and look through the goal.  The primary goal is that we want a few re-tries before we raise an exception.  We believe that about 2 or 3 retries (without exception) is the correct number of retries before we raise an exception.  Note, once we raise an exception the Sidekiq system will then use it's own retry mechanism.

In essence, we have two retry mechanisms:

- The internal to the job retry where we don't raise an exception within a few attempts
- The external (e.g. Sidekiq handler) that will move the job into the retry queue (because an exception was thrown)

For the internal job retry, we "reschedule" which means we're creating a new job (which instantiates a new object) and sending it to the normal queue.  Because we create a new job (and Ruby object) we need need to pass a parameter that we have from the first call (e.g. the time to live) and decrement that counter for the next job.

commits.message:
Adding additional ways we call "perform"

Prior to this commit, I was only looking for `Job.perform`.  However in
reading more of the code, there were places where we would send a
message to `Job` (e.g. `method_name = :perform_now;
Job.send(method_name))`

With this commit, I'm handling the aforementioned case.

I should note that in the code we also have something analogous to:

```ruby
"My#{job_category}Job.constantize.perform"
```

That is currently not found by the logic.
Adding an example that I can run
Updating configuration to almost eliminate literate

Refactoring to remove conditional (#663)

Refactoring Bulkrax::ApplicationParser conditional

Prior to this commit, we had an if statement that would check if the
given parser was a `Bulkrax::CsvParser`, if so it would go down one
logic pathway.  If not, it would call a different pathway.  Each pathway
required knowledge of the implementation details of the parser.  The
`Bulkrax::CsvParser` required knowledge of a non-public API
setup (e.g. a method not defined on `Bulkrax::ApplicationParser`).

With this commit, we're favoring a single entry point for all parsers.
Moving the logic down to the parser and allowing for polymorphism of the
`Bulkrax::CsvParser` to provide it's different implementation.

One additional change is calling save on the importer before we create
the objects.  This was something not called in the `Bulkrax::CsvParser`
and based on the comment could have created a problem.

pull_request.title: Refactoring to remove conditional
pull_request.body:
Prior to this commit, we had an if statement that would check if the given parser was a `Bulkrax::CsvParser`, if so it would go down one logic pathway.  If not, it would call a different pathway.  Each pathway required knowledge of the implementation details of the parser.  The `Bulkrax::CsvParser` required knowledge of a non-public API setup (e.g. a method not defined on `Bulkrax::ApplicationParser`).

With this commit, we're favoring a single entry point for all parsers. Moving the logic down to the parser and allowing for polymorphism of the `Bulkrax::CsvParser` to provide it's different implementation.

One additional change is calling save on the importer before we create the objects.  This was something not called in the `Bulkrax::CsvParser` and based on the comment could have created a problem.

pull_request.title: Refactoring to remove conditional
pull_request.body:
Prior to this commit, we had an if statement that would check if the given parser was a `Bulkrax::CsvParser`, if so it would go down one logic pathway.  If not, it would call a different pathway.  Each pathway required knowledge of the implementation details of the parser.  The `Bulkrax::CsvParser` required knowledge of a non-public API setup (e.g. a method not defined on `Bulkrax::ApplicationParser`).

With this commit, we're favoring a single entry point for all parsers. Moving the logic down to the parser and allowing for polymorphism of the `Bulkrax::CsvParser` to provide it's different implementation.

One additional change is calling save on the importer before we create the objects.  This was something not called in the `Bulkrax::CsvParser` and based on the comment could have created a problem.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -35,6 +31,21 @@ def perform(file_set, file_id, filepath = nil)
       file_set.reload
       file_set.update_index
       file_set.parent.update_index if parent_needs_reindex?(file_set)
+    rescue StandardError => e
+      if time_to_live.positive?
+        # It's possible we can recover from this, so we'll give it another go.
+        logger.warning(
+          "WARNING: FileSet ID=\"#{file_set_id}\" error for #{self.class}: #{e}. " \
+          "Retries remaining #{time_to_live - 1}."
+        )
+        CreateDerivativesJob.perform_later(file_set, file_id, filepath, time_to_live - 1)
+      else
+        logger.error(
+          "ERROR: FileSet ID=\"#{file_set_id}\" error for #{self.class}: #{e}. " \
+          "No retries remaining.  Backtrace: #{e.backtrace}"
+        )
+      end
+      return false
comment.body:
Do we want this to `return false` in all cases?  My assumption would be that we would return false if we reschedule or encounter an error.  But return true if we complete successfully.

All of which might be mute because the return value may be inconsequential.

comment.body:
This will not work as desired.

Each time we call `CreateDerivativesJob.perform` we instantiate a new object; note the `def perform` is an instance method and `CreateDerivativesJob.perform` is a class method call.  This means the instance variable will always be 2.

What we need is to pass this as a parameter.

Here is an example of that implementation: https://gitlab.com/notch8/adventist-dl/-/blob/c924c8aed10d354d2c4992981b0905ef15a120f3/app/jobs/index_plain_text_files_job.rb

issue.title: An admin's changes are not persisted on the Work Sharing tab when Admin Set does not allow access grants
issue.body:
### Descriptive summary

Admins **always** have access to the Sharing tab on the work form, even if the Admin Set the work is deposited in doesn't allow access grants. When an admin fills out the Add Sharing form and submits it, the UI indicates it submits successfully; however, the change does not get persisted. 

This is because the permissions parameters get silently thrown out of the request if the admin set does not allow access grants (see [WorkForm.sanitize_params](https://github.com/samvera/hyrax/blob/a0f8455fa373b94f2700b0a47fd55084ba7fde6d/app/forms/hyrax/forms/work_form.rb#L156-L165)). 

This bug has been reproduced in HEAD (as of a0f8455) on [Nurax](https://nurax-dev.curationexperts.com/?locale=en). 

### Rationale

There is a mismatch in what the UI says the user has access to, and what the user can actually do. The UI should be consistent with the user's ability. 

### Expected behavior

Two options: 

1. An admin should not be able to see a work's sharing tab (or should get an error in the UI) if the work's admin set does not allow access grants 
2. An admin's changes to a work's sharing should persist, even if the work's admin set does not allow access grants 

### Actual behavior

An admin's changes to a work's sharing do not get persisted when the work's admin set does not allow access grants. 

### Steps to reproduce the behavior

1. Login as an admin 
3. Create a new Admin Set with a mediated deposit workflow 
4. Deposit a new Work into the Admin Set created in step 2 
5. Edit the work 
6. Click on the Sharing tab 
7. Under "Add Sharing", select any group/user/access and click Add 
8. Click the "Save changes" button 
9. Edit the work again 
10. Click on the Sharing tab 
11. Verify the change you just made was not persisted under the "Currently Shared With" section 

### Related work

To my understanding, admins **should** always have access to the Sharing tab on the work form as evidenced by #4898. Does this mean the second option under Expected Behavior is the correct path forward?

issue.title: Allow indexing (and full text searching) of text/plain files
issue.body:
### Descriptive summary

Allow for the text content of `text/plain` files to be searched and indexed.

This feature does not exist in HEAD @bd2bcffc33e183904be2c175367648815f25bc2b.

### Rationale

Provide the rationale or user story that describes "why" this issue should be addressed. Especially if this is a new feature or significant change to the existing implementation.

### Expected behavior

A `text/plain` file is indexed during derivative creation process.

### Actual behavior

A `text/plain` file is ignored during the derivative creation process, and thus the text is never extracted.

### Steps to reproduce the behavior

Create a plain text file (using Notepad or your text editor); in that file add some unique text.  Now create a new work and attach that file.  Save the work (wait for characterization and processing to complete).  Then go to the application's /catalog page and search for that unique text.

### Related work

There exists code for Adventist's digital library that handles two cases:

- Newly uploaded `text/plain` files
- Existing `text/plain` files

This could be ported over with minimal effort.  We would want to ensure that we run extract the text if and only if we are doing full text work.

commits.message:
Adding custom ignore file

In adding that command, I can ignore the denote/scientist directroy for
most git operations; but with projectile's file find, I can see those
files.

Adjust div class to reflect partial name

**Prior to this commit**, when you were on the `/importers/new` page you
would see the form fields for the OAI ingester; even though you hadn't
selected that parser.

The reason is that in Bulkrax the name of the partial is used to hide
the section with a HTML class attribute that is the named
partial (e.g. `_oai_adventist_fields.html.erb` and
`class="oai_adventist_fields"`)

Below is the [Bulkrax code demonstrating that functionality][1]:

```
  <% Bulkrax.parsers.map{ |p| p[:partial]}.uniq.each do |partial| %>
  if($('.<%= partial %>').length > 0) {
    window.<%= partial %> = $('.<%= partial %>').detach()
  }
  <% end %>
```

**With this commit**, when you haven't selected a parser, there will be
no parser fields.  Then when you select the parser, the browser will
render the associated fields.

[1]:https://github.com/samvera-labs/bulkrax/blob/e88d0ea349afda5b3068836aa36ef86c93d4c62d/app/assets/javascripts/bulkrax/importers.js.erb#L112-L116

issue.title: I127 fix CreateDerivativesJob bug
issue.body:
@jeremyf noticed that the previous implementation wouldn't have worked because the counter instance variable would've been reset at each instantiation of the job. 

This MR updates the counter and is inspired by [this](https://gitlab.com/notch8/adventist-dl/-/blob/c924c8aed10d354d2c4992981b0905ef15a120f3/app/jobs/index_plain_text_files_job.rb) implementation.

comment.body:
I want to step back from my suggestions and look through the goal.  The primary goal is that we want a few re-tries before we raise an exception.  We believe that about 2 or 3 retries (without exception) is the correct number of retries before we raise an exception.  Note, once we raise an exception the Sidekiq system will then use it's own retry mechanism.

In essence, we have two retry mechanisms:

- The internal to the job retry where we don't raise an exception within a few attempts
- The external (e.g. Sidekiq handler) that will move the job into the retry queue (because an exception was thrown)

For the internal job retry, we "reschedule" which means we're creating a new job (which instantiates a new object) and sending it to the normal queue.  Because we create a new job (and Ruby object) we need need to pass a parameter that we have from the first call (e.g. the time to live) and decrement that counter for the next job.

Adding additional ways we call "perform"

Prior to this commit, I was only looking for `Job.perform`.  However in
reading more of the code, there were places where we would send a
message to `Job` (e.g. `method_name = :perform_now;
Job.send(method_name))`

With this commit, I'm handling the aforementioned case.

I should note that in the code we also have something analogous to:

```ruby
"My#{job_category}Job.constantize.perform"
```

That is currently not found by the logic.
Adding an example that I can run
Updating configuration to almost eliminate literate

Refactoring to remove conditional (#663)

Refactoring Bulkrax::ApplicationParser conditional

Prior to this commit, we had an if statement that would check if the
given parser was a `Bulkrax::CsvParser`, if so it would go down one
logic pathway.  If not, it would call a different pathway.  Each pathway
required knowledge of the implementation details of the parser.  The
`Bulkrax::CsvParser` required knowledge of a non-public API
setup (e.g. a method not defined on `Bulkrax::ApplicationParser`).

With this commit, we're favoring a single entry point for all parsers.
Moving the logic down to the parser and allowing for polymorphism of the
`Bulkrax::CsvParser` to provide it's different implementation.

One additional change is calling save on the importer before we create
the objects.  This was something not called in the `Bulkrax::CsvParser`
and based on the comment could have created a problem.

This will not work as desired.

Each time we call `CreateDerivativesJob.perform` we instantiate a new object; note the `def perform` is an instance method and `CreateDerivativesJob.perform` is a class method call.  This means the instance variable will always be 2.

What we need is to pass this as a parameter.

Here is an example of that implementation: https://gitlab.com/notch8/adventist-dl/-/blob/c924c8aed10d354d2c4992981b0905ef15a120f3/app/jobs/index_plain_text_files_job.rb

Therefore their filesets should not have thumbnails. - http://pcdm.org/file-format-types#Markup - http://pcdm.org/use#PreservationFile - [ ] Everything else should process a thumbnail.

issue.title: An admin's changes are not persisted on the Work Sharing tab when Admin Set does not allow access grants
issue.body:
### Descriptive summary

Admins **always** have access to the Sharing tab on the work form, even if the Admin Set the work is deposited in doesn't allow access grants. When an admin fills out the Add Sharing form and submits it, the UI indicates it submits successfully; however, the change does not get persisted. 

This is because the permissions parameters get silently thrown out of the request if the admin set does not allow access grants (see [WorkForm.sanitize_params](https://github.com/samvera/hyrax/blob/a0f8455fa373b94f2700b0a47fd55084ba7fde6d/app/forms/hyrax/forms/work_form.rb#L156-L165)). 

This bug has been reproduced in HEAD (as of a0f8455) on [Nurax](https://nurax-dev.curationexperts.com/?locale=en). 

### Rationale

There is a mismatch in what the UI says the user has access to, and what the user can actually do. The UI should be consistent with the user's ability. 

### Expected behavior

Two options: 

1. An admin should not be able to see a work's sharing tab (or should get an error in the UI) if the work's admin set does not allow access grants 
2. An admin's changes to a work's sharing should persist, even if the work's admin set does not allow access grants 

### Actual behavior

An admin's changes to a work's sharing do not get persisted when the work's admin set does not allow access grants. 

### Steps to reproduce the behavior

1. Login as an admin 
3. Create a new Admin Set with a mediated deposit workflow 
4. Deposit a new Work into the Admin Set created in step 2 
5. Edit the work 
6. Click on the Sharing tab 
7. Under "Add Sharing", select any group/user/access and click Add 
8. Click the "Save changes" button 
9. Edit the work again 
10. Click on the Sharing tab 
11. Verify the change you just made was not persisted under the "Currently Shared With" section 

### Related work

To my understanding, admins **should** always have access to the Sharing tab on the work form as evidenced by #4898. Does this mean the second option under Expected Behavior is the correct path forward?

comment.body: There's some observed challenges in a general and "right proper" fix.

issue.title: Allow indexing (and full text searching) of text/plain files
issue.body:
### Descriptive summary

Allow for the text content of `text/plain` files to be searched and indexed.

This feature does not exist in HEAD @bd2bcffc33e183904be2c175367648815f25bc2b.

### Rationale

Provide the rationale or user story that describes "why" this issue should be addressed. Especially if this is a new feature or significant change to the existing implementation.

### Expected behavior

A `text/plain` file is indexed during derivative creation process.

### Actual behavior

A `text/plain` file is ignored during the derivative creation process, and thus the text is never extracted.

### Steps to reproduce the behavior

Create a plain text file (using Notepad or your text editor); in that file add some unique text.  Now create a new work and attach that file.  Save the work (wait for characterization and processing to complete).  Then go to the application's /catalog page and search for that unique text.

### Related work

There exists code for Adventist's digital library that handles two cases:

- Newly uploaded `text/plain` files
- Existing `text/plain` files

This could be ported over with minimal effort.  We would want to ensure that we run extract the text if and only if we are doing full text work.

commits.message:
Adding custom ignore file

In adding that command, I can ignore the denote/scientist directroy for
most git operations; but with projectile's file find, I can see those
files.

Adjust div class to reflect partial name

**Prior to this commit**, when you were on the `/importers/new` page you
would see the form fields for the OAI ingester; even though you hadn't
selected that parser.

The reason is that in Bulkrax the name of the partial is used to hide
the section with a HTML class attribute that is the named
partial (e.g. `_oai_adventist_fields.html.erb` and
`class="oai_adventist_fields"`)

Below is the [Bulkrax code demonstrating that functionality][1]:

```
  <% Bulkrax.parsers.map{ |p| p[:partial]}.uniq.each do |partial| %>
  if($('.<%= partial %>').length > 0) {
    window.<%= partial %> = $('.<%= partial %>').detach()
  }
  <% end %>
```

**With this commit**, when you haven't selected a parser, there will be
no parser fields.  Then when you select the parser, the browser will
render the associated fields.

[1]:https://github.com/samvera-labs/bulkrax/blob/e88d0ea349afda5b3068836aa36ef86c93d4c62d/app/assets/javascripts/bulkrax/importers.js.erb#L112-L116

pull_request.title: Adjust div class to reflect partial name
pull_request.body:
**Prior to this commit**, when you were on the `/importers/new` page you would see the form fields for the OAI ingester; even though you hadn't selected that parser.

The reason is that in Bulkrax the name of the partial is used to hide the section with a HTML class attribute that is the named partial (e.g. `_oai_adventist_fields.html.erb` and `class="oai_adventist_fields"`)

Below is the [Bulkrax code demonstrating that functionality][1]:

```
  <% Bulkrax.parsers.map{ |p| p[:partial]}.uniq.each do |partial| %>
  if($('.<%= partial %>').length > 0) {
    window.<%= partial %> = $('.<%= partial %>').detach()
  }
  <% end %>
```

**With this commit**, when you haven't selected a parser, there will be no parser fields.  Then when you select the parser, the browser will render the associated fields.

[1]:https://github.com/samvera-labs/bulkrax/blob/e88d0ea349afda5b3068836aa36ef86c93d4c62d/app/assets/javascripts/bulkrax/importers.js.erb#L112-L116

```shell
❯ rg SETTINGS__SOLR__URL
ops/env.conf
23:env SETTINGS__SOLR__URL;
```

With this commit, I'm restoring that setting.  I'm unclear if this will
fix the [issue that I encountered and reported in this Slack thread][1].

issue.title: Adjust div class to reflect partial name
issue.body:
**Prior to this commit**, when you were on the `/importers/new` page you would see the form fields for the OAI ingester; even though you hadn't selected that parser.

The reason is that in Bulkrax the name of the partial is used to hide the section with a HTML class attribute that is the named partial (e.g. `_oai_adventist_fields.html.erb` and `class="oai_adventist_fields"`)

Below is the [Bulkrax code demonstrating that functionality][1]:

```
  <% Bulkrax.parsers.map{ |p| p[:partial]}.uniq.each do |partial| %>
  if($('.<%= partial %>').length > 0) {
    window.<%= partial %> = $('.<%= partial %>').detach()
  }
  <% end %>
```

**With this commit**, when you haven't selected a parser, there will be no parser fields.  Then when you select the parser, the browser will render the associated fields.

[1]:https://github.com/samvera-labs/bulkrax/blob/e88d0ea349afda5b3068836aa36ef86c93d4c62d/app/assets/javascripts/bulkrax/importers.js.erb#L112-L116

issue.title: I127 fix CreateDerivativesJob bug
issue.body:
@jeremyf noticed that the previous implementation wouldn't have worked because the counter instance variable would've been reset at each instantiation of the job. 

This MR updates the counter and is inspired by [this](https://gitlab.com/notch8/adventist-dl/-/blob/c924c8aed10d354d2c4992981b0905ef15a120f3/app/jobs/index_plain_text_files_job.rb) implementation.

comment.body:
I want to step back from my suggestions and look through the goal.  The primary goal is that we want a few re-tries before we raise an exception.  We believe that about 2 or 3 retries (without exception) is the correct number of retries before we raise an exception.  Note, once we raise an exception the Sidekiq system will then use it's own retry mechanism.

In essence, we have two retry mechanisms:

- The internal to the job retry where we don't raise an exception within a few attempts
- The external (e.g. Sidekiq handler) that will move the job into the retry queue (because an exception was thrown)

For the internal job retry, we "reschedule" which means we're creating a new job (which instantiates a new object) and sending it to the normal queue.  Because we create a new job (and Ruby object) we need need to pass a parameter that we have from the first call (e.g. the time to live) and decrement that counter for the next job.

commits.message:
Adding additional ways we call "perform"

Prior to this commit, I was only looking for `Job.perform`.  However in
reading more of the code, there were places where we would send a
message to `Job` (e.g. `method_name = :perform_now;
Job.send(method_name))`

With this commit, I'm handling the aforementioned case.

I should note that in the code we also have something analogous to:

```ruby
"My#{job_category}Job.constantize.perform"
```

That is currently not found by the logic.
Adding an example that I can run
Updating configuration to almost eliminate literate

Refactoring to remove conditional (#663)

Refactoring Bulkrax::ApplicationParser conditional

Prior to this commit, we had an if statement that would check if the
given parser was a `Bulkrax::CsvParser`, if so it would go down one
logic pathway.  If not, it would call a different pathway.  Each pathway
required knowledge of the implementation details of the parser.  The
`Bulkrax::CsvParser` required knowledge of a non-public API
setup (e.g. a method not defined on `Bulkrax::ApplicationParser`).

With this commit, we're favoring a single entry point for all parsers.
Moving the logic down to the parser and allowing for polymorphism of the
`Bulkrax::CsvParser` to provide it's different implementation.

One additional change is calling save on the importer before we create
the objects.  This was something not called in the `Bulkrax::CsvParser`
and based on the comment could have created a problem.

pull_request.title: Refactoring to remove conditional
pull_request.body:
Prior to this commit, we had an if statement that would check if the given parser was a `Bulkrax::CsvParser`, if so it would go down one logic pathway.  If not, it would call a different pathway.  Each pathway required knowledge of the implementation details of the parser.  The `Bulkrax::CsvParser` required knowledge of a non-public API setup (e.g. a method not defined on `Bulkrax::ApplicationParser`).

With this commit, we're favoring a single entry point for all parsers. Moving the logic down to the parser and allowing for polymorphism of the `Bulkrax::CsvParser` to provide it's different implementation.

One additional change is calling save on the importer before we create the objects.  This was something not called in the `Bulkrax::CsvParser` and based on the comment could have created a problem.

given parser was a `Bulkrax::CsvParser`, if so it would go down one
logic pathway.  If not, it would call a different pathway.  Each pathway
required knowledge of the implementation details of the parser.  The

pull_request.title: Refactoring to remove conditional
pull_request.body:
Prior to this commit, we had an if statement that would check if the given parser was a `Bulkrax::CsvParser`, if so it would go down one logic pathway.  If not, it would call a different pathway.  Each pathway required knowledge of the implementation details of the parser.  The `Bulkrax::CsvParser` required knowledge of a non-public API setup (e.g. a method not defined on `Bulkrax::ApplicationParser`).

With this commit, we're favoring a single entry point for all parsers. Moving the logic down to the parser and allowing for polymorphism of the `Bulkrax::CsvParser` to provide it's different implementation.

One additional change is calling save on the importer before we create the objects.  This was something not called in the `Bulkrax::CsvParser` and based on the comment could have created a problem.

       file_set.reload

       file_set.parent.update_index if parent_needs_reindex?(file_set)
+    rescue StandardError => e
+      if time_to_live.positive?

+        logger.warning(
+          "WARNING: FileSet ID=\"#{file_set_id}\" error for #{self.class}: #{e}. " \
+          "Retries remaining #{time_to_live - 1}."

+      else

+        )
+      end
+      return false
comment.body:
Do we want this to `return false` in all cases?  My assumption would be that we would return false if we reschedule or encounter an error.  But return true if we complete successfully.

All of which might be mute because the return value may be inconsequential.

comment.body:
This will not work as desired.

Each time we call `CreateDerivativesJob.perform` we instantiate a new object; note the `def perform` is an instance method and `CreateDerivativesJob.perform` is a class method call.  This means the instance variable will always be 2.

What we need is to pass this as a parameter.

Here is an example of that implementation: https://gitlab.com/notch8/adventist-dl/-/blob/c924c8aed10d354d2c4992981b0905ef15a120f3/app/jobs/index_plain_text_files_job.rb

Therefore their filesets should not have thumbnails. - http://pcdm.org/file-format-types#Markup - http://pcdm.org/use#PreservationFile - [ ] Everything else should process a thumbnail.

payload.description: Hyrax is a Ruby on Rails Engine built by the Samvera community. Hyrax provides a foundation for creating many different digital repository applications.

issue.title: An admin's changes are not persisted on the Work Sharing tab when Admin Set does not allow access grants
issue.body:
### Descriptive summary

Admins **always** have access to the Sharing tab on the work form, even if the Admin Set the work is deposited in doesn't allow access grants. When an admin fills out the Add Sharing form and submits it, the UI indicates it submits successfully; however, the change does not get persisted. 

This is because the permissions parameters get silently thrown out of the request if the admin set does not allow access grants (see [WorkForm.sanitize_params](https://github.com/samvera/hyrax/blob/a0f8455fa373b94f2700b0a47fd55084ba7fde6d/app/forms/hyrax/forms/work_form.rb#L156-L165)). 

This bug has been reproduced in HEAD (as of a0f8455) on [Nurax](https://nurax-dev.curationexperts.com/?locale=en). 

### Rationale

There is a mismatch in what the UI says the user has access to, and what the user can actually do. The UI should be consistent with the user's ability. 

### Expected behavior

Two options: 

1. An admin should not be able to see a work's sharing tab (or should get an error in the UI) if the work's admin set does not allow access grants 
2. An admin's changes to a work's sharing should persist, even if the work's admin set does not allow access grants 

### Actual behavior

An admin's changes to a work's sharing do not get persisted when the work's admin set does not allow access grants. 

### Steps to reproduce the behavior

1. Login as an admin 
3. Create a new Admin Set with a mediated deposit workflow 
4. Deposit a new Work into the Admin Set created in step 2 
5. Edit the work 
6. Click on the Sharing tab 
7. Under "Add Sharing", select any group/user/access and click Add 
8. Click the "Save changes" button 
9. Edit the work again 
10. Click on the Sharing tab 
11. Verify the change you just made was not persisted under the "Currently Shared With" section 

### Related work

To my understanding, admins **should** always have access to the Sharing tab on the work form as evidenced by #4898. Does this mean the second option under Expected Behavior is the correct path forward?

comment.body: There's some observed challenges in a general and "right proper" fix.

issue.body:
As folks explore how to create parsers and mappings for their local Bulkrax implementations, in our experience (Software Services by Scientists.com) they need a way to clean-up relationships.

To resolve this ticket, we should add the following:

- A job to clean up all of tenant's relationships
- A job that clean's up one importer's relationship

These could initially called via the command line.

issue.title: Allow indexing (and full text searching) of text/plain files
issue.body:
### Descriptive summary

Allow for the text content of `text/plain` files to be searched and indexed.

This feature does not exist in HEAD @bd2bcffc33e183904be2c175367648815f25bc2b.

### Rationale

Provide the rationale or user story that describes "why" this issue should be addressed. Especially if this is a new feature or significant change to the existing implementation.

### Expected behavior

A `text/plain` file is indexed during derivative creation process.

### Actual behavior

A `text/plain` file is ignored during the derivative creation process, and thus the text is never extracted.

### Steps to reproduce the behavior

Create a plain text file (using Notepad or your text editor); in that file add some unique text.  Now create a new work and attach that file.  Save the work (wait for characterization and processing to complete).  Then go to the application's /catalog page and search for that unique text.

### Related work

There exists code for Adventist's digital library that handles two cases:

- Newly uploaded `text/plain` files
- Existing `text/plain` files

This could be ported over with minimal effort.  We would want to ensure that we run extract the text if and only if we are doing full text work.
